qas.question: What result might someone who has received a TB vaccination get from the Mantoux test?
In combination with skin tests, are IGRAs associated with an increase or decrease in sensitivity?
Which test has fewer false positives: IGRAs or the Mantoux skin test?
What liquid would you need from a patient to perform IGRAs?
What is used to test for sarcoidosis?
What incorrect result may someone who has not gotten the TB vaccination get?
What environmental substance are IGRAs affected by?
What has more false-positives than the Mantoux tuberculin test?

context: The <b5_0>Mantoux tuberculin skin test<b5_0/> is often used to screen people at high risk for TB. Those who have been previously immunized may have a <a0_0><b6_0>false-positive<b6_0/><a0_0/> test result. The test may be falsely negative in those with sarcoidosis, Hodgkin's lymphoma, malnutrition, and most notably, active tuberculosis. <a1_0>Interferon gamma release assays<a1_0/> (<a3_0><b8_0>IGRAs<b8_0/><a3_0/>), on a <a4_0>blood<a4_0/> sample, are recommended in those who are positive to the Mantoux test. These are not affected by immunization or most environmental <b7_0>mycobacteria<b7_0/>, so they generate fewer false-positive results. However, they are affected by M. szulgai, M. marinum, and M. kansasii. IGRAs may <a2_0>increase<a2_0/> sensitivity when used in addition to the skin test, but may be less sensitive than the skin test when used alone.
